evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, showing consistent patterns without contradictory information.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario, including timing and crew interactions.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_t3_prefinal is resistant to common defeaters and alternative explanations.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: Lack of warnings or questioning implies communication/coordination breakdown
The roles of headset operator, wingman, and tug instructor are critical for communication during pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication or coordination preventing or addressing the incident
If the crew had clear, documented communication protocols that were followed
If the incident was caused by external factors unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) directly indicates a lack of communication or coordination among the crew during the pushback, as no warnings or corrective communication were given despite the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast fence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the extent and impact of communication breakdown; no explicit statements of communication failure but implied by lack of warnings

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction during the event
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft systems during the pushback
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25; all evidence describes a pushback operation and human factors without mention of mechanical/control failure (H1-H13).

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario, including timing and crew interactions.

assumptions: The described crew interactions and timing are representative of the key features in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If timing or crew interactions differed significantly from the scenario described

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes communication and coordination issues among the crew during the pushback, including lack of warnings and assumptions made by crew members (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in the extent of communication breakdown due to assumptions and lack of explicit warnings

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed a marking or environmental deficiency present and identifiable during the specified phase.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or identification of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and their significance are correctly understood and applied as per the evidence.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed the pushback was stopped at the TRP or the collision was caused by external factors unrelated to procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents the procedural deviation during pushback with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4), with clear location and procedural context (H7). Multiple eyewitness accounts confirm the deviation and lack of corrective action (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit procedural documentation or checklist excerpts are provided to confirm the exact procedural requirements or deviations.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal, reflecting typical operational characteristics and deviations.

assumptions: The described TRP and clearance dimensions are standard for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback operations at this location.
The roles and qualifications of personnel reflect typical operational staffing and training.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the deviation was due to an unusual or non-typical operational factor not consistent with known procedures or training for this aircraft and pushback scenario.
If the TRP or operational environment was significantly different from what is described, invalidating the alignment claim.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes the procedural deviation during pushback for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, including the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4), the known clearance and TRP location (H7), and the roles and awareness of involved personnel (H8, H9, H12, H13), supporting that the deviation aligns with typical operational characteristics and deviations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists regarding the sufficiency of visual signals and communication effectiveness during pushback, which may affect interpretation of typicality.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal.

assumptions: The statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
No other unreported communications or warnings occurred during the pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed that the tug instructor ignored clear warnings or signals from the team
If the headset operator or wingman had explicitly warned or attempted to stop the pushback but were ignored
If procedural guidelines clearly mandated different actions that were feasible and ignored

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows that the procedural deviation was not challenged or countered by involved personnel during the event, indicating the deviation withstands scrutiny against alternative explanations or counterarguments.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

defeaters: Evidence of any mechanical or control system malfunction or failure during the hist_t3_prefinal phase would change my mind.
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence (H1-H13) mentions or supports a mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase; the evidence focuses on tug operation, pushback procedure, and collision with the blast fence.

assumptions: Assuming that the historical reports accurately reflect the communication events and no unreported communications occurred.
defeaters: If contradictory evidence showed crew members communicated warnings or challenged actions effectively, this would change the assessment.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the incident

children_spec.statement: Communication equipment was operational and accessible to the crew

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_t3_prefinal is resistant to common defeaters and alternative explanations.

defeaters: If there was clear evidence that all involved personnel had full situational awareness and actively tried to prevent the failure but could not, resistance to defeaters would be higher.

He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that the tug instructor's control was not effectively challenged or corrected by others (H8, H10, H12), and that visual signals were insufficient and the TRP was small (H8, H13). This suggests the mechanical/control failure was not strongly resistant to defeaters or alternative explanations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct technical analysis of mechanical/control failure resistance; reliance on human factors and procedural descriptions.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

defeaters: Direct evidence showing the environmental or marking deficiency explicitly aligns or does not align with the key features and criteria for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase
Evidence of formal criteria or standards for the TRP markings and their compliance status

He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates the TRP marking exists and is known but is small and the visual signals for stopping are insufficient (H7, H8, H13). There is no direct statement that the environmental or marking deficiency aligns with the key features and criteria for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal phase, only indirect indications of marking size and signaling issues.

node.statement: Crew had sufficient time and opportunity to communicate during the event

assumptions: Communication includes both verbal and non-verbal signals relevant to safety-critical events.
Crew roles and qualifications imply expected communication responsibilities.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, timely verbal or non-verbal communication warnings were given and acknowledged among crew during the event.
If the crew had clear, established communication protocols that were followed and documented during the pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates that although crew were physically present and in communication, key warnings or concerns about the pushback passing the TRP were not communicated among crew (H8, H10, H12), suggesting insufficient effective communication opportunity or use.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether communication opportunities were sufficient but not utilized, or insufficient due to situational constraints.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

assumptions: The TRP marking is considered part of the environmental or marking deficiency identification
Robustness against defeaters includes clear visibility and effective communication/signaling
defeaters: If there was evidence that the TRP marking was clearly visible and unambiguous to all personnel during the pushback
If there were effective communication protocols or signals that reliably prevented passing the TRP
If the headset operator or wingman had actively warned the tug instructor of the impending collision

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows the TRP marking existed and was known to personnel (H7, H11), but the visual signals and marking size were insufficient to prevent the pushback past the TRP (H8, H13), indicating the identification of the deficiency was not robust against exceptions during the inspection.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the effectiveness of visual signals and personnel awareness of the TRP marking

node.statement: Availability of necessary ground support equipment for pushback

assumptions: Presence of personnel (headset operator, wingman) implies some ground support equipment availability.
Non-mandatory use of marshalling wands suggests equipment was likely available but not used.
defeaters: Direct evidence of missing or unavailable ground support equipment would change the assessment.
If marshalling wands or other equipment were mandatory and missing, that would lower availability.
If the headset operator or wingman had better visibility or communication tools, availability might be higher.

defeaters: If there was clear evidence that all involved personnel had full situational awareness and actively tried to prevent the failure but could not, resistance to defeaters would be higher.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that the tug instructor's control was not effectively challenged or corrected by others (H8, H10, H12), and that visual signals were insufficient and the TRP was small (H8, H13). This suggests the mechanical/control failure was not strongly resistant to defeaters or alternative explanations.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct technical analysis of mechanical/control failure resistance; reliance on human factors and procedural descriptions.
